q: What are the symptoms of chlamydia?
a: Most people with chlamydia do not notice any symptoms. However, if symptoms do occur, they may include pain when urinating, unusual discharge from the genitals, pain in the abdomen, and bleeding between periods.

q: How can chlamydia be transmitted?
a: Chlamydia can be transmitted through unprotected vaginal, anal, or oral sex, sharing unwashed sex toys, and contact between genitals even without penetration. It can also be passed from a pregnant woman to her baby.

q: Is chlamydia a serious infection?
a: Chlamydia is usually treatable with antibiotics, but if left untreated, it can lead to long-term health problems. In women, it can cause pelvic inflammatory disease, ectopic pregnancy, and infertility. In men, it can cause painful and swollen testicles.

q: How can I get tested for chlamydia?
a: To get tested for chlamydia, you can visit a sexual health clinic, genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinic, or your GP. Testing can be done with a urine test or a swab test.

q: What is the treatment for chlamydia?
a: Chlamydia can usually be treated with a short course of antibiotics, such as doxycycline or azithromycin. It's important to complete the full course of treatment and inform your sexual partner(s) to prevent reinfection.

q: How can chlamydia be prevented?
a: Using condoms consistently during sex, whether vaginal, anal, or oral, and avoiding sharing unwashed sex toys can help prevent the spread of chlamydia. Regular testing and informing sexual partners can also help in prevention.

q: How soon do symptoms of an STI appear?
a: The timeframe for the appearance of symptoms varies depending on the specific STI. In the case of chlamydia, symptoms may appear within a few weeks or months, or they may not present any symptoms at all.

q: What should I do if I suspect I have an STI?
a: If you suspect you have an STI, it's important to get tested as soon as possible. You can visit a sexual health clinic, GUM clinic, or your GP for testing and appropriate treatment if needed.

q: Are sex toys safe?
a: Sex toys can be safe if they are used and maintained properly. It's important to clean sex toys before and after each use and to use barrier methods, such as condoms or dams, to reduce the risk of STI transmission.

q: What services do sexual health clinics provide?
a: Sexual health clinics, also known as GUM clinics, provide a range of services including STI testing, treatment and counseling, contraception advice, and sexual healthcare for all individuals regardless of age or gender.

q: What are the symptoms of chlamydia?
a: Most people with chlamydia do not notice any symptoms, but some may experience pain when peeing, unusual discharge from the vagina, penis, or bottom, pain in the tummy (women), and pain and swelling in the testicles (men). If you think you're at risk or have any symptoms, it's recommended to get tested.

q: How is chlamydia transmitted?
a: Chlamydia is usually spread through unprotected sex or contact with infected genital fluids. It can also be passed from a pregnant woman to her baby. However, it cannot be passed through casual contact or sharing personal items.

q: Is chlamydia a serious infection?
a: Although chlamydia can usually be treated with antibiotics, it can be serious if left untreated. In women, it can lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), ectopic pregnancy, and infertility. In rare cases, it can cause complications in men, such as epididymitis (inflammation of the testicles). Early testing and treatment are important.

q: How to get tested for chlamydia?
a: Chlamydia testing can be done through a urine test or a swab test. You can get a free and confidential test at a sexual health clinic, genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinic, or GP surgery. In England, women under 25 may be offered a test when visiting some health services. Testing is recommended once a year for sexually active individuals.

q: What is the treatment for chlamydia?
a: Chlamydia can usually be treated with antibiotics, such as doxycycline or azithromycin. It's important to finish the full course of treatment and to inform your current and recent sexual partners, who should also be tested and treated. Under-25s should have a follow-up test after 3 to 6 months as they have an increased risk of reinfection.

q: How can chlamydia be prevented?
a: Using a condom during sex, including oral and anal sex, can help prevent the spread of chlamydia. It's also important to avoid sharing sex toys and to wash or cover them with a new condom between each person using them. Regular testing and open communication with sexual partners are key to prevention.

q: When do symptoms of STIs appear?
a: The time it takes for STI symptoms to appear can vary depending on the specific infection. It's important to get tested if you think you may have been exposed to an STI, even if you don't have symptoms, as some infections may not cause noticeable symptoms but can still be transmitted.

q: What should I do if I suspect I have an STI?
a: If you suspect you have an STI, it's important to get tested and treated. You can visit a GP, community contraceptive service, or local genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinic for testing. They can provide guidance and support and help prevent the spread of infections.

q: Are sex toys safe?
a: Using sex toys can be safe as long as proper hygiene practices are followed. It's important to wash or cover them with a new condom between each person using them to prevent the spread of infections. Regular cleaning and maintenance of sex toys are necessary for safe use.

q: What services do sexual health clinics provide?
a: Sexual health clinics, also known as genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinics, provide a range of services including testing and treatment for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), contraception advice, pregnancy testing, and sexual health counseling. They offer confidential and non-judgmental care for all individuals.
